Authors:
Graziele Santos Lima, Kledson Mendes Santos, Ana Paula
Oliveira Barros, Ailton Reis, Alexandre Reis Machado, Cristina Maria
Souza-Motta, Kamila Camara Correia, Sami Jorge Michereff
Title:
Diversity of anastomosis groups of Rhizoctonia associated
with brassicas different regions of Brazil
Keywords:
Bayesian Inference  Ceratobasidium sp.  ITS sequences 
Rhizoctonia solani  Vegetables
Abstract:
Seventy-eight Rhizoctonia isolates were collected from
vegetable brassicas presenting typical Rhizoctonia symptoms in Brazil.
The isolates were identified by phylogenetic analysis of the internal
transcribed spacer (ITS) region of ribosomal DNA and tested for
pathogenicity and aggressiveness. Sixty-eight isolates were identified
as R. solani and ten isolates as binucleate Rhizoctonia. The most
prevalent AG was AG-4-HGI (83.3% of isolates), followed by AG-A (7.7%),
AG-1-IB (2.6%), AG-G (2.6%), AG-R (2.6%), and AG-2-2IIIB (1.3%).
AG-4-HGI was found in all regions of brassicas collection in Brazil.
Isolates from all AGs, with the exception of AG-A, induced symptoms in
detached leaves of kale. AG-4 HGI and AG-2-2IIB isolates were
significantly more aggressive. This study was the first report of the
occurrence of AG-4-HGI, AG-2-2IIIB, AG-A, AG-G and AG-R infecting
brassica plants in Brazil. Knowledge of these anastomosis groups is
extremely important for understanding the epidemiology of the disease
and forward development of management strategies.
